subject: Re: Digest Number 1408
author: Rick
full_text:
Thanks for the anecdote Leslie.  Looks like we're tracking down the
actual citations for what Edison claimed in that area, so I am hopeful
we'll be able to definately clear it all up!

Rick

--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, Aquarius <laustin@...> wrote:
>
> Hi, Rick.
> 
> Back in the day when I was working on my Ph.D. thesis, which
involved some technical stuff about the history of the development of
multitrack recording, and the effects of electronic mediation on vocal
music performance, I came across a reference to Edison. I apologize,
but I have long since lost the original citation, so I can't offer it
to you.
> 
> What I remember from my research at the time was that Edison did
indeed believe that the voices of spirits could be recorded, and in
fact his work on what turned out to be the phonograph (capturing
voices on wax cylinders, later on flat platters, later on what we call
records) was intended to eventually lead to being able to record
spirit voices. Apparently he got as far as figuring out how to record
incarnate human voices <g>, but stopped before he got any spirit
voices. I seem to dimly remember some comment that he thought his
technology needed to be further developed, but he didn't pursue it, at
least not in any way that has ever been publicly disclosed.
> 
> Hope this helps, though the citation is lacking!
> 
> Best,
> 
> Leslie
>

> > I suppose ultimately, it doesn't really matter if Edison made a
telephone to the dead or not.  >Modern researchers in this field will
have to stand on their own results anyway, and if they've >managed to
discover something that Edison never achieved, good for them!
> >
> >I have also heard varied claims: that Edison did make this box;
that Edison was working on it but >never finished it; that Edison was
joking when he mentioned working on it.  So for my own sake, I'd >like
to know the real story.
